titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
I was prepared to ride into Boston this morning at ten, but detained by a succession of visitors till after the Noon Bell of Quincy Meeting house had rung. Mr Curtis first came with a bundle of papers, and his Letter-book respecting the Execution of Mr W. N. Boylston’s Will. We went over together the abstract of the Will, which I had prepared and he mentioned the provisions of it which have been carried into Execution— He proposes one Exchange of a small strip of land at Roxbury, for an equal number of feet, with his brother Mr Joseph
Curtis, for the mutual convenience of both Estates; and he had prepared a Deed to be executed by the Executors; but he had taken one of the printed forms of Deeds which will not suit the Conveyances to be made under this Will— I observed that there must be a form of Deed, adapted to the provisions of the Will, and to be used for all the Deeds which we may be called to execute— He proposed that my Son Charles should be employed to prepare it— The most essential point now to be accomplished is to draw from England the sum which has been received by P. Vaughan, for the sum recovered from the French Government on the claim of Thomas Boylston— I gave Mr Curtis my copy of the Will; to procure a copy of the probate upon it— The visitors who followed Mr Curtis, came from motives of civility or of curiosity— Mr Wick is a foreigner from Gothenburg— Mrs Keating, daughter of Judge Hopkinson— It was so late when I reached Boston, that I had time only to leave a Card at Mr J. Welles’s, to call at Mr E. Cruft’s, and at the U.S. Branch Bank, where I received the last dividend upon my 6. per Cent Stocks, and gave the Check to Charles— I went with him and dined at Mr P. C. Brooks’s at Medford. Mr Barnard the member of the last Congress from Rochester, Mr and Mrs Everett, Mrs Frothingham and Miss Phillips were there. Mrs Brooks much better, particularly in Spirits than this day fortnight— She urged me to stay over the Night, but I had promised to return home— She spoke of Charles’s Marriage, and requested that Mrs Adams and I would then pass the Night there— Returning home I passed through Boston, and stop’d to pay a short visit to judge Joseph Hall, who invited me to dine with him next Saturday. I got home about 8 in the Evening; wet with a shower and chilled with cold— Yesterday was at high Summer heat. The thermometer fell in the course of the last Night, about 30 degrees— I went to bed quite unwell
2. IV:15. Sunday.

Communion day. Heard Mr Whitney from Ecclesiastes 5.1. “Keep thy foot when thou goest to the House of God, and be more ready to hear than to give the sacrifice of fools: for they consider not that they do evil” And in the afternoon from Philippians 4.4. [“]Rejoice in the Lord alway: and again I say rejoice.” The Communion was administered after the ordinary morning service; and the Sermon had reference to that Institution. It was upon the duties of a Christian in regard to his Deportment at Public worship— He said the expression keep thy foot, had allusion, to the practice in primitive times of putting off the Shoe, in communion with the deity; and referred to the command given to Moses at the burning bush— This may be questionable— The expression is in the figurative Style, peculiar to the writings of Solomon. For the figurative language of Solomon, of David, of Job, and of Isaiah, all partaking of the general character of Eastern imagery have each a distinguishing mark of its own— And this difference it would be a suitable Sunday’s occupation to trace and mark out these differences. May I not undertake it?— I read this day Dr. Freeman’s Sermons 3. and 4. of his new publication— On the character of a wise and amiable woman, and upon Old Age— This last gave me satisfaction—the other was too superficial— I began the Answer to a
Letter from my Son John, but soon after returning from the afternoon’s meeting there came a succession of visitors, till the close of the Evening— William Greenleaf and Price Greenleaf were of the number— After a Night of severe Rhumatic pains, I was easier this morning, and recovering from them through the day.
3. IV:15. Monday.

Mr Whitney and his Son George paid me a morning visit. Lieutt. T. B. Adams was here most of the day, but went towards Evening with Elizabeth H. Foster to a party at Miss Marston’s— We bathed at the wharf between one and two; and the Sun being out very warm the Lieutenant coming from Charleston S.C., observed that it would not be safe to incur such exposure to the Sun, there— The tide was coming up, but the wind was blowing fresh down the Creek— It took me 238 strokes of the arms to go down and 293 to come up from wharf to wharf. The effect of the wind therefore upon the water was much stronger than that of the tide— I this day removed for the purpose of my daily writing from the bed-chamber to the Library room in the farm-house; much less convenient and pleasant; but to which I must endeavour to accommodate myself. After dinner I took the Siesta of two hours; and answered my Son John’s last Letter— Read part of the Correspondence of Mr Curtis, my Co-Executor of the Will of W. N. Boylston, with Petty Vaughan, his Agent in England, upon which I made a few Minutes— Read also some of Madame du Deffand’s Letters, and of these three or four were interesting— The account of the dismission of the Duke de Choiseul from the command of the Swiss guards; and the criticisms upon Bussy-Rabutin, and Madame de Sevigné were especially amusing; but I could not read without disgust the coolness with which this Lady tells Walpole, that Bussy lived in habitual incestuous connection with his own daughter— Her character of Bussy is admirably drawn; and with much more acuteness and discrimination than that drawn by Walpole. Charles came out late from Boston.
4. IV:15. Tuesday.

There was a copious Thunder Shower this morning, and a light rain continued through great part of the day— Charles went to Boston and returned this Evening, and I was without interruption of Visitors— I commenced my daily occupation in the Library, and wrote there till dinner time— My task—Short Letters in answer to Genl. La Fayette and W. B. Lawrence; a minute in the Quarto Volume, Copy of the first Book of Braintree Town Records; and entries in my Cash Account Book— After dinner, returning to the Bed-chamber I read the remainder of the Correspondence of my Co-Executor Nathl. Curtis, with Petty Vaughan and others— Charles brought me out one from Mr Curtis, enclosing one just received from Mr Vaughan— These papers have partly put me in possession, of the present condition of Mr W. N. Boylston’s Affairs; but leave several questions still to be satisfied— I removed to the Library a part of my father’s
papers, and propose commencing to-morrow the arrangement of them. The work that I undertake must be pursued with steadiness and perseverance; and in its progress will require the exercise of other qualities—Prudence, Moderation, Justice, and an entire controul over my own feelings— Nor can it succeed without indefatigable Industry— These qualities, with continued health can be dispensed only from above; and all will be of little avail, unless my mind can be tempered to its subject; its vision cleared of obscurity—its weakness fortified with power, that the object of my affection and reverence may be known to future ages as he was; and that the narrative of his life, like his life itself may contribute to the welfare and improvement of mankind.
5. IV:15. Wednesday.

Mr Chamberlin came and transferred to me his Share in the Quincy Canal Corporation which he acknowledged before my brother. Dr Sprague, a Clergyman late of West Springfield, but now about removing to Albany paid me a visit of perhaps two hours. He has written me several Letters, and sent me two or three of his publications— A man of inquisitive mind, and a sort of curiosity, perhaps better adapted to other professions than his. One of his publications is an account of his travels in Europe from which he returned about three years since— Worth and Sugar, were apparently Friends, and came to visit the Railway, and the Ex-President. Towards Evening I rode to return the visit of Captain John Whitney, but he was not at home; and I returned by a circuit through Braintree— The Lieutenant was here morning, and evening; but returned home to pass the Night— Charles went to Boston this Morning and to Medford this Evening— I began upon the collection of minutes and memoranda preparatory to the biographical Memoir of my father. I propose to devote henceforth three hours a day to that portion of my business— My brother reminded me that it is this day twenty years since I embarked at Charlestown, for Russia— I embark this day upon a more perilous, perhaps a more difficult expedition.
6. IV:15. Thursday.

Proposing to write one page every day of the preparatory matter of my intended work, I began by collecting some of the Books which I possess relating to the first Settlement of New-England. Looking successively into them, matters of curiosity presented themselves, which absorbed the morning so that I was barely able to write my second page before dinner— The Volume, which I accidentally purchased at Berlin, contains three pamphlets, each somewhat rare, and all, relating to this subject— Thomas Morton’s Book, purports to be printed at Amsterdam in 1637. It is in three Books— The first giving some account of the Indian natives— The second a description of the Country, and the third is a disguised and mystified narrative of his own adventures with the Colonists. But it is told in a conceited and figurative Style, with interspersion of poetry, or rather of rhymes,
and Satirical fictitious names applied to the principal persons of the Plymouth and Massachusetts Colonies— This Book is to be further examined, and compared with the other cotemporary publications, and with Winthrop’s Journal. I also looked into Mather’s Magnalia, and read his Lives of the three Thomas Shepherds, the first of whom married the daughter of William Tinge, and was my ancestor— Their daughter having married Daniel Quincy, the father of John Quincy my great-grandfather, whose name I bear— Mather mentions several publications of the first and second Thomas Shepherd, probably not recoverable— He gives also an abstract of Instructions given by the second Thomas Shepherd to the third, upon his entering College, and says that he had received similar instructions from his father— They have much of the religious enthusiasm of the age; but are otherwise admirable— The quotation of Proverbs 14.23. is peculiarly impressive, and should be printed on the Memory of every man throughout life— After dinner, and the nap I read a few Letters of Madame du Deffand, and part of a book lately sent me by Mr G. W. Erving, upon the antiquity and perfection of the Basque Language— I worked towards Sunset an hour with the Spade— Charles brought me out Letters from my wife, my Son John, and Dr Waterhouse.
7. IV:15. Friday.

Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— Mr Tufts and Mrs Tarbell paid us a morning visit— Mr Hardwick came to speak of two strips of land which he wishes to purchase of me—one near his house which he has more than once mentioned heretofore; and one an angle of Saltmarsh upon the Mount Wollaston farm— He spoke also of the encroachment of the Sea upon part of the Beach of that farm, and advised me to have Stakes driven down to prevent it— Mr Wilde came to offer me three Acres of Saltmarsh for Sale and for which he asked 175 dollars, saying that his father had been offered 200 for them. Mr Curtis came this afternoon; and said his Son wished to have the Deed of the Half-Acre of Land upon which he proposes to build, so that he may begin to dig his Well in a dry time, September being considered the best Month for that purpose— I told him I expected to have the mortgage upon that farm discharged next week, and that my wife would be here to join in the Deed about the 25th. so that his Son might depend upon having it by the end of the Month.— Bathed at the wharf at five this afternoon with my Son Charles, and my brothers three Sons, the Lieutenant and John and Joseph— My brother, and his daughter Abigail were here; going to Mr T. Greenleaf’s— Continuing my researches, I found in the seventh Volume of Massachusetts Historical Collections, in Dr Holmes’s History of Cambridge, a biographical account of the first Thomas Shepard— It was his Son, the Minister of Charlestown who married Anna Tyng, daughter of William Tyng, and joined her in the Indenture of partition of William Tyng’s Estate in 1661. by which the Mount Wollaston farm was assigned to her—and she gave it 48 years afterwards by Will to John Quincy, the Son of her daughter, who had married Daniel Quincy.— This second Thomas Shepard was born in 1634. the year of his father’s emigration to this Country. He died 22. Decr. 1677.
He was graduated at Harvard College in 1653. and at the execution of this Indenture was 27. years of age— His Son the third Thomas Shepard, was born in 1658. and was no doubt by this same Anna Tyng— Daniel Quincy was born the 7th. of February 1650. I find also in the 10th. Volume of the Historical Collections a Memoir of Edward Tyng by Timothy Alden junr. which says that William Tyng, spent his life at Braintree, and left no Posterity; both of which are mistakes.
8. IV:15. Saturday.

I dined at Judge Joseph Hall’s in Boston; and intended to have returned several visits there, but it was past eleven before I could leave home; past twelve before I reached Boston, and after examining several marble slabs at Mr. Cary’s the Stone-cutter; and calling at Mr James H. Foster’s; it was past one, before I came to my Son Charles’s Office— The heat was then excessive and it was too late for visiting— At half past two I went to the Judge’s with Charles— The company, with Mrs Hall, his Sister, and their Son, was only Fitch Hall, and Joseph Russell— There was a moderate Thunder Shower after dinner—after which I called again at Mr Foster’s, where I had ordered my Carriage to wait for me. My brother’s Son Isaac Hull Adams came there, and I brought him out with me and left him at his father’s— Judge Hall lent me for perusal a number of John Neal’s Yankee, concerning Jeremy Bentham, and J. T. Austin’s last 4th of July Oration; the last of which I read after returning home.
9. IV:15. Sunday.

A Hot Summer’s day, Heard Dr Parkman of Boston; from Ecclesiastes 9.11. “I returned, and saw under the Sun, that the race is not to the swift, nor the battle to the strong, neither yet bread to the wise, nor yet riches to men of understanding, nor yet favour to men of skill; but time and chance happeneth to them all.” There is an excellent Sermon of Sterne upon this text, of which Mr Parkman had perhaps unconsciously borrowed something in the composition of his Discourse. The text is one of those melancholy Truths, which abound in the Book of Ecclesiastes, and of which the experience of every age is the same as that of Solomon— But it is the exception and not the rule: and the Sentiment in this verse should be taken in connection not only with the next verse, but with all the remaining part of the Chapter— The moral conclusion from the whole is in the last verse— Mr Parkman’s afternoon Sermon was from Habakkuk 3.17 “Although the fig-tree shall not blossom, neither shall fruit be in the vines; the labour of the olive shall fail, and the fields shall yield no meat; the flock shall be cut off from the fold, and there shall be no herd in the Stalls: 18. Yet, I will rejoice in the Lord, I will joy in the God of my Salvation.” This Sentiment should be associated with the observation of the morning’s text— One is the Statement of a fact, constantly exemplified in the history of mankind, and if duly considered essential to the moral Government of the Universe— The other is the temper becoming the virtuous man, under all the visitations
of Providence, to preserve a cheerful and rejoicing Spirit, and a firm reliance upon the God of Salvation. This is the duty of man, and it forbids yielding to despondency or despair— Mr Parkman came home and dined with me; as did Mr Degrand who came out from Boston— Mr Parkman spoke much of the works recently published of Dr Parr, which I have not yet seen— Degrand spoke of the Politics of State, and in the event of Governor Lincoln’s retirement, said the intention of the Republicans was to support H. A. S. Dearborn in his place; which I approved— Lieutt. Adams dined with us— Mrs T. B. Adams with her Sons Isaac Hull and Joseph Harrod called in the Evening. Isaac Hull, went to Boston with Mr Degrand. Mr Greenleaf and his daughters were also here; and I had conversation with him, on the proposed establishment of a Classical School in this Town, which I fear will be long postponed.
10. IV:15. Monday.

Morning bath immediately after breakfast. Swam from wharf to wharf 255 strokes of the arms each way—in 16 1/2 minutes, and as quick as I was able. Adam Hardwick came to offer me again to sell me a lot of Salt-marsh land— I had neither means nor inclination to purchase; he finally informed me that his house and land were under attachment since last March, by the Executor of a Dr Hall, of Boston, who had been the husband of Hardwick’s daughter, and to whom he had given a Note for 250 dollars— He said he had received no notice of the suit, and complained that it had been commenced in resentment against him, because he had advised his daughter to claim her thirds of Dr Hall’s Estate, instead of the provision he had made for her by Will which was limited to her widowhood— He thought a young woman ought not to be so restricted— But he acknowledged that the Executor had demanded payment of the Note or a mortgage of his house for security; to which he had objected, without absolutely refusing it— His own Story made out an indifferent case against the Executor, and I advised him to settle the Note, and pay the costs of the Suit, before they should be aggravated by judgment and execution— Mr Beale called for a short time towards Evening with his Son— Charles came out from Boston, and brought me several Letters, among which one from my wife. The morning was warm and sultry, but a North-west wind in the afternoon swept off all the clouds and brought a clear and cold Evening. I pursued my enquiries into the history of my fathers family since their Settlement in this Country— I find them here, in respectable but subordinate standing, immediately after the first formation of the Town, but can trace them no further— Since then their births, marriages and deaths are ascertained: the old record book of the town exhibits them at various times in the municipal Offices, and the Will of the first Joseph Adams shews that he was a considerable brewer. The annals of the family are short and simple; but how much of human history; how much of happiness; how much of affliction has been enjoyed and endured by them in the century preceding my father’s birth of which nothing can henceforth be known. I shall collect all the little incidents concerning them that can be gleaned, and commit them to writing— They are records of humble life, but there is nothing in them of which a descendant need be ashamed. Cogita Majores, is the dictate of Virtue as well as of Nature— After dinner and the nap I read
a number of Letters from my Mother to Harriet Welsh, which she has sent to me. Written from 1811 to 1815. and some of which deeply affected me— There are bundles of subsequent Letters till within a few days of my mother’s death—
11. IV:30. Tuesday.

I had written Notes on Saturday, inviting, Dr. and Mrs Waterhouse, President Quincy, Mr Curtis and Mrs Boylston to dine with me this day— Mr Quincy’s Son, told me on Sunday at Meeting that his father was called unexpectedly to the State of New-York, and could not be here this day. Mr Curtis came alone, but he had not received my Note of invitation, in which that to Mrs Boylston was enclosed— Dr and Mrs Waterhouse did not come, whence I conclude my Note to the Doctor equally failed of reaching him— Mr Curtis brought out several papers, relating to the Execution of W. N. Boylston’s Will, and we attended the Probate Court, before and after dinner, at French’s Tavern where it is held. I took out the Letter of Guardianship of Ward Nicholas and of Thomas Boylston; but gave no Bond, the Will having directed that none should be required; and the boys having no property, until after the decease of Mrs Boylston— The report of the Commissioners on the claim of John L. Boylston awards to him 5000 dollars for his Services, from which is to be deducted the sum already advanced him by Mr Curtis— This award was received and approved by the Judge, who entered upon the award, an order for its execution, of which a copy was furnished to Mr Curtis— He also brought and we laid before the Judge an extract from the Will; concerning several bequests to the Inhabitants of Princeton to be paid after the death of Mrs Boylston— There is one of an Acre of Land, in perpetuity to be used as burying ground for himself and his descendants— There is some doubt whether they will accept this bequest; as it will impose some duties upon them, and perhaps an expence of keeping fences in repair; without corresponding benefit to them. The question was whether the Town could accept the bequests beneficial to them, and decline that which may prove burdensome. The judge advised that the copy of all the provisions in the Will relating to these bequests should be sent to the Selectmen of the Town, that the Inhabitants might be called to act upon them, as they shall think fit, and he said he thought they would accept the whole; so that there would be no question for him to decide— Mr Petty Vaughan in his last Letter to Mr Curtis, hints a proposal that the Executors of W. N. Boylston should take out here an Administration de Bonis non, upon the Estate of Thomas Boylston, that they may give him a full discharge for remitting to them the sum recovered from the French Government, in the name of T. Boylston— We mentioned this to the judge who declined issuing the Letters of Administration, and said he believed it was only Petty Vaughan’s wish to keep the money, of which he has got possession— Mr Curtis said this was rather a hard suspicion upon Mr Vaughan, upon which Judge Robbins said—Yes Sir, but the man has got no money; and he went
away from here, three or four years ago, exceedingly embarrassed. Old Benjamin Vaughan would not do such a thing; but when a man is pressed for money— Here he stop’d; but the idea occurred both to Mr Curtis and me that Judge Robbins’s thoughts were running upon Events nearer home, and other persons than the Vaughan’s— He said however that at all Events he could not issue the Letters of Administration; there being no Estate of Thomas Boylston, not administered upon in this County— Ward N. Boylston’s Letters of Administration with the Will of Thomas Boylston annexed were taken out, first in London, and then with an exemplification of the Will, in the County of Suffolk here; and the judge said, and Mr Haven the Register confirmed, that where an Administration was left incomplete by the death of the Administrator, the new Administration must be taken out in the same County, where it had been first granted.— Something was said about the property thus recovered, and the judge said he remembered having heard of the transaction in which it had originated—a Speculation in oil during the War of the American Revolution; in which Lieutenant Governor Gill had been concerned, and which had been charged against him as unpatriotic— We met at the Court in the afternoon Mr Loud of Weymouth, Daniel Greenleaf and Lemuel Brackett; who witnessed and took the acknowledgment of my Execution of the Deed of Exchange of a small strip of Land at Roxbury, with Joseph Curtis. The deed had been redrawn, according to the form I had proposed, and was already executed and acknowledged by Nathl. Curtis— I gave him an Account of a Charge of my Son George, for drawing a Power of Attorney, which Charles had given me this Morning: Mr Loud told me that he had received all his papers from MrBuren which he believed was in consequence of my having written to him. He said he would call some day and take the papers which he left with me. Charles came out this day before dinner.
12. IV:15. Wednesday.

Dr Waterhouse came and dined with us. He did not receive my Note of invitation for yesterday till yesterday afternoon. He has been spending several weeks at New-York, with one of his daughters residing there, married to a Son of Professor Ware. He visited Mr Oliver Wolcott at his Son in Law Gibbs’s, and had much conversation with him on the Politics of former Times. He says Wolcott told him that all I had said upon the subject of projects of disunion, was true; but that he knew much more of the matter than I did. The Doctor told me also some of the particulars of the controversy now in progress between Dr Holmes, and his Parish at Cambridge— He thinks the principal cause of the dissatisfaction given by Dr Holmes to his people, is by the neglect of his appropriate Pastoral duties, by the devotion of his Time, to a new and enlarged edition of his Annals— A majority of the Society have dismissed him; and engaged others to preach in his place; but about one third of the Parish adhere to him, and he now preaches for them at the Court House— The controversy is breeding pamphlets— I lent Dr Waterhouse the manuscript of my reply to the Boston Confederates. Mr Bussey called with his Grandson
F. Head, and while they were here there came four young men—natives of this State; settled at Charleston South-Carolina, and now visiting here; with whom Mr Bussey had much conversation concerning the Tariff, and his manufacture of broadcloth— I received an invitation from the Mayor Aldermen and Common Council of Boston, to attend the annual Visitation of the Schools on the 19th. which I shall decline— Charles came out to dinner. T. B. Adams junr. was here in the morning but did not stay to dine. The business of yesterday, and the visitors of this day, absorbed all my time excepting that given to the fixed daily task.
13. IV:30. Thursday.

Charles went into Boston this Morning, and to Medford this Evening Harvey Field, brought me a tax Bill for the year, amounting to 100 dollars and some Cents— He renewed his proposals to sell me three shares of the Quincy Canal, and also one of the Notes, but we could not agree upon the price— He said he had been viewing the ground of my fresh meadow to be brought over to English grass, and he thought it would cost 65 dollars an Acre, which for 20 Acres would make a sum of 1300 dollars; and startled me— He said he proposed to view it again with a man who had experience in reclaiming Land of the same kind, and would then see me again— Mr Hobart came with a young man named Walker, and two boys, for a visit of curiosity— Hobart said he was of the Abington family, and Cousin of Aaron Hobart the former Member of Congress— In the afternoon Mr Davis came out with Mr Sully, who has been engaged to finish the full length portrait of me, the head of which was painted by G. Stuart in October 1825. for Mr W. N. Boylston, and which he has given to the University. I agreed to go in to Boston, Saturday Morning to sit— There was some conversation about the costume of dress suitable for the picture; and upon which there had been a difference of opinion between Stuart and me— Sully will agree with me. My brother was here in the Evening, and his Son the Lieutenant most of the day. I bathed and swam from wharf to wharf and back, at ten this morning—16 minutes in the water though suffering with the lumbago, which has afflicted me for several days.
14. IV:15. Friday.

Mr Morse came early this morning, as Agent for a Chaise maker at Charlestown named Eaton; earnestly inclined to sell me a Chaise, taking my old one, in part payment, for a novelty of the present fashion— I gave him little encouragement, but he came again after dinner, with a Chaise in the newest taste, in which my Son Charles, discovered many grave defects, and which did in no wise suit me. We did not trade— Mr Brigham, Treasurer of the Quincy Canal Corporation came to repeat a proposition, that he and Mr Beale had made to me before to take up all the Notes
due by the Corporation, at par, and paying the interest due upon them; which I declined. Mr Brigham himself had also Shares and Notes to dispose of; upon the price of which we could not agree— Mr Shepherd paid me a Morning visit, with two of his friends from Louisiana, Linton of New-Orleans and Duncan of Natchez. And a family from Cayuga New-York, returning from a pilgrimage to Plymouth, asked permission to view the grounds round the house— They had the dress and Manners of Quakers, but Mr Howland told me he was a descendant from the Pilgrims, and that an ancestor of his name was one of the Associates of the May-flower— Charles came from Boston before dinner, and the Lieutenant spent the day with us— I bathed with him at 11. A.M—and swam from wharf to wharf and back in 15 minutes. The distance between the wharves as I swim is rather short of a quarter of a Mile— Read some Letters of Madame du Deffand.
15. IV:30. Saturday.

I went into Boston and stood, for Mr Sully; for the finishing of the Portrait, painted by G. Stuart in October 1825— He was at the House at the corner of Hamilton Place, owned by Mr Quincy; and where he resided when he was Mayor of Boston— I was with him about two hours. He took only a miniature pencil drawing upon paper; but is to take the canvass with him to Philadelphia, and to finish it there— While I was with him Mr Brimmer, and Mr Furness the Unitarian Minister at Philadelphia called in— Sully told me that Elliot Cresson was here, and came with him from Philadelphia. I agreed to meet him again on Monday: and had only time left to pay a visit to Mrs Humphreys, but she was not at home— I met in the Street Judge Hall, and Mr B. Gorham— I called at Charles’s Office, where John Thomas came with the Carriage— I went to Mrs. A. Otis’s; there took up Harriet Welsh, who came with me to Quincy— We were here at half past two. A young man came and announced himself as Midshipman Howard, of the Navy; recently returned from the Coast of Brazil. He said he was the Officer against whom the British Minister complained in 1824. for retaking certain fishing Schooners captured on the borders of New-Brunswick. He also told me that Commodore Creighton, was recalled from the Coast of Brezil, and was coming home under charges of tyranny and oppression— William Greenleaf was here this afternoon— I brought out with me the third Volume of Hutchinson’s History, of which I read some pages. I received from Dr Waterhouse a Letter, enclosing one from Jonathan Sewall to the former Judge Lee, dated 29. September 1787. curious as descriptive of his own situation and feelings at that Time; and especially for a long paragraph respecting my father— I wrote a page of my genealogical fragments this afternoon— There was from two till seven O’Clock this morning, one of the heaviest thunder storms that I ever experienced— It struck and damaged the house of Mr Chamberlin, near Webb’s Bridge. The Meeting-House Bell was consequently rung about half an hour between three and four. It kindled a fire also upon Paddocks Island, and struck, both in Braintree and Boston. Alpheus Spear was here this afternoon.
16. IV:30. Sunday.

Heard Mr Whitney from 1. Thessalonians 5.9—[“]For God hath not appointed us to wrath, but to obtain salvation, by our Lord Jesus Christ, 10. Who died for us, that, whether we wake or sleep, we should live together with him” and in the afternoon, from Matthew 1.18. “Now the birth of Jesus Christ was on this wise”— Both these were controversial Unitarian Sermons, and that of the afternoon was an argument against the veracity and authenticity of the text— Mr Whitney was not so dogmatical in excluding the first Chapters of Matthew and of Luke from the Canon of Scripture as I have heard the late Mr Little, but he announced the doubts entertained by many learned men, and gave reason to his hearers to believe that he concurred in the belief that these Chapters were spurious. There was a very boisterous child baptized by the name of Angelina, whose name and ways had some analogy with the text and Sermon of Mr Whitney. My brother’s Sons, the Lieutenant, and Isaac Hull came and dined with us, and Coll. Josiah Quincy spent part of the Evening with us— I read a Christmas Sermon of Dr. Freeman’s upon Alms-giving, and finished the first Chapter of the third Volume of Hutchinson’s History.
17. IV:30. Monday.

Mr Cary came from Boston this morning; with several designs, of monumental Tablets for my examination, and Selection. I chose the simplest of them all, a tablet in two Columns, which he promised to have ready to be put up by the first of October next— Mr Hardwick brought me the papers relating to the dower of his daughter; widow of Dr Thayer, of Boston, which I had not immediately time to examine— I went into Boston, and took home, Elizabeth Foster, who has been passing a fortnight with us. I stood an hour for Mr Sully who finished his pencil sketch, from which he is to finish the Portrait by Stuart. I asked Mr Sully’s advice, with regard to the preservation of Pictures on Canvas. He said they should be washed with a spunge of Chamois skin, dipped in tepid water every autumn; and covered with a black gauze in Summer: and should be suspended, so far from the Wall that the Air may circulate behind them— He mentioned also several precautions necessary at the time of painting upon Canvas and shortly after essential to the durability of the Pictures, particularly that one coat of Paint should not be laid over another till the first is dry, and that the picture should not be varnished till it has been at least six months painted— The Portraits at my house in Quincy have suffered already for want of some of these attentions, and unless better kept hereafter will soon perish— After finishing with Mr Sully, I proposed paying several visits, but meeting Mr George Blake near his house, went in with him, and spent the spare hour with him— Saw there for the first time his Son who has just recovered from a severe fit of sickness. I called twice at Mr James H. Fosters, and while there President
Quincy came in, and apologized for his non-attendance with me, on the 11th. instt. at the Probate Court— He returned last Friday from New-York. On calling at Charles’s Office, I found him gone, and on returning home at 3. O’Clock found him already there— T. B. Adams junr. passed the day here— The short afternoon was chiefly absorbed in looking over the first Volume of Savage’s Edition of Winthrop’s Journal; in which I see there is matter prolific of occupation for me— Received Letters from my wife and my Son John—
18. IV:30. Tuesday— Charles 22.

My Son Charles who was this day twenty-two years old went this morning to Boston, and came back to dinner— At four in the afternoon he went with the Carriage and Horses and John Thomas, to meet my wife who is coming from Washington— John is to come with her, as far as New-York, and Charles to go and join her there; leaving the Carriage and horses with John Thomas at Providence, and come from New-York there in the Steam-boat— A Heavy rain began about eight O’Clock this morning and continued the whole day— Charles went off in the midst of it—but it soon afterwards abated. I was confined all day to the house and Office; wrote two short Letters, and read a few pages of Hutchinson’s third volume, and most of the third book of T. Morton’s New-English Canaan. From the figurative Style in which it is written, I can but very imperfectly understand it. Why he wrote thus is not explained— The first of his three books is a very flattering description of New-England— The second an account of the Savage Inhabitants, and the third, a Satirical and Allegorical Account of the Plymouth and Massachusetts Colonies in which he gives an Account of their treatment of him. He represents it as very outrageous, but imputes it all to his revels and his May pole at Ma-reMount. All the other Accounts mention Morton has having been one of Captain Wollaston’s Company; but in his book not one word is said of Wollaston, nor is his name mentioned. The other Accounts all say that Wollaston’s Settlement was made in 1625. but Morton says expressly that he arrived in the Country in June 1622. and in the title page to his Book, first published at London in 1632 he declares he had ten years experience of the Country. Here is a historical problem to resolve, upon which much enquiry may be spent, much time lost, and after all, of what use would be the result? to confirm what Voltaire calls the Pyrrhonism of History—
19. IV:30. Wednesday.

The day was fair and cool. Josiah Adams was here doing Carpenter’s Work: putting up beds, and mentioned to me that Henry Wood had the keys of the Tombs. I desired him to ask Mr Wood to call upon me, which he did this Evening and delivered to me both the Keys— He has had them ever since the day when the remains of my father and mother, were removed from the Tomb in the burying ground, to that under the Meeting-house. March 1828— The Lieutenant, and his Sisters were here in the afternoon. Judge Cony, an old Man
from Augusta, in the State of Maine, aged 77— came to pass the Night with us. I have had heretofore a slight acquaintance with him, and before the Separation of Maine from Massachusetts, he was for many successive years a member of one or the other House of the Legislature— and some one years of the Council— I passed the day at home and resumed the exercise of the Spade for an hour and a half— I find it irksome; and the labour too violent; but since my disuse of the ride on horseback I feel that I cannot omit such exercise with impunity— I began this day too the examination of my father’s papers; and took up his earliest Journal that I can find— It is on a pamphlet of small duodecimo size, apparently 2 1/2 Sheets of small foolscap paper folded into that form containing forty pages, the last nine of which are blank. On the first outside page is written “Worcester January 14th 1756. Wednesday.”—on the inner page is a notice in 8 lines of the Earthquake of 18. Novr. 1755—and then 29 pages of Journal from the 14th. of January to the 29th. of August 1756—not regularly kept; and written in so small a hand that I have great difficulty in reading it— I did read about three fourths of it, and was then interrupted— Some years since two Letters from my father to his Classmate Charles Cushing, dated 1. April and 19. October 1756. were published in the Nantucket Gazette— copies of them made by Mrs S. B. Clarke were among my Son George’s papers, and the Lieutt. has recopied them at my request in my father’s last Letter Book. They and the Journal illustrate each other.
20. IV.30. Thursday.

After breakfast this morning, I walked with judge Cony to Mr P. Whitney’s; but he was gone to Cambridge and Boston, and his Son told us that he was in the practice of going to Boston every Thursday when the weather was fair. Returning, we went into the Meeting House and afterwards into the burying yard. Judge Cony made an observation that the Wall pews should have been made to front the central aisles, the reason of which he explained. We descended into the Sepulchre where the remains of my father and mother are deposited; and afterwards visited the Granit Tombstones, erected by my father to the memory of his Ancestors—Henry, Joseph Senior, and Elizabeth Baxter his wife, Joseph junior, and Hannah Bass his wife, and John and Susanna Boylston his wife— Upon this visit I observed, first that the marble slab fitted in to the Granit Stone over Henry Adams, and upon which the inscription is carved, is already broken at one corner. Secondly that the Stones of some of the other monuments are loosened, and call for repair— Thirdly that of all the old Granit Gravestones in the Yard, the inserted marble Slab upon which was the inscription is invariably gone. fourthly that those upon which the inscription is engraved on the Granite, the characters are so much effaced that they are illegible— The oldest grave stones in the yard are of Granite Those of the second age are of Slate Stone, and much thinner— There is an error upon the inscription of Henry Adams’s Stone, which says that the only one of his Sons who remained at Braintree was Joseph— There is evidence that Peter also remained here.
Judge Cony expected that Mr N. Curtis of Roxbury would have come to take him in to Boston, but he did not— Mr Gray, Mr Ticknor and Mr Bailey were afternoon visitors; and Coll. Quincy and Mr Seaver in the Evening. T. B. Adams junr. was here this morning, and again in the Evening. He had been upon a party at Squantum with Mr G. W. Beale, at the opening of his new built house— This party was to have been last Tuesday; and I had an invitation to it from Mr Beale— It was then postponed on account of the weather, and this day I was engaged at home with my company. This also deterred me from going to A. Spear’s at Mount Wollaston, as I had promised— My brothers wife went last week on a visit to her mother at Haverhill— Thomas B. Adams junr. and his Sister Abigail, are going there to-morrow, to return with her next week— Thomas engaged to take Harriet Welsh in to Boston to-morrow Morning. Reuben Sanborn is a crazy man who came to talk to me of his visions.
21. IV:15. Friday.

Judge Cony left us this morning, and returned in the Stage to Boston. Harriet Welsh went also with T. B. Adams junr— Ruth Turner passed the day here; and in the afternoon Mrs Thayer and Mrs Faxon were here. I had examined all the papers of Mrs Thayer which her father A. Hardwick had left with me—and found that although she had been treated very roughly in point of form by the Executor of her husband, the proceedings at the probate Office appeared to have been conformable to the Law. I found that while the Law gives to the widow when there are no children, one half the personal property in case of intestacy; and when there is a Will, allows the Widow to waive its provisions and claim her dower, it gives her with regard to the personal Estate neither the benefit of intestacy nor of the Will— This was Mrs Thayer’s case— Her husband had given her part of his real Estate during widowhood. She preferred taking her Dower—and thereby forfeited what the Will had given her of personal Estate. I bathed between four and five this afternoon, and swam from Wharf to Wharf and back in 15 minutes. Mr Price Greenleaf overtook me, but went to the beach to bathe— I walked over Mount Wollaston to A. Spear’s, but did not find him at home— Returned by the road— I finished the perusal of my father’s first manuscript Journal— It contains very few facts relating to himself— The most important of them is the notice of his contract with Mr Putnam, to read Law, under his direction two years— There are some metaphysical Speculations— Some self-examination and censure— Some vigorous Resolutions of study, and frequent complaints of dreaming away time. The Journal ceases immediately after he commenced the study of the Law— I wrote a single page of Memoranda, and find this work so irksome, that I almost despair of my own perseverance— I read also a few pages of Winthrop’s Journal; Savage’s Edition— Every step that I take in this progress, opens to me a new field of enquiry; introduces persons, merely enough to excite the curiosity to know more of them; and draws my attention to multitudes of Books, many of which I do not possess. The interest of Winthrop’s Journal is exceedingly increased by the Notes of Savage— But I perceive a necessity for drawing a boundary line around my pursuit—my time will else be all absorbed, in scrutiny and investigation without producing any useful result— After dinner I read some pages of the third Volume of Hutchinson’s History; and in the Evening, a few Letters of Madame du Deffand— I anticipated those relating to the illness and death of Louis 15.
22. IV. Saturday— Lighted lamp.

Morning visit from Elliott Cresson; accompanied by a young friend of his from Philadelphia by the name of Norris. Cresson and Sully are to depart next Monday from Boston, upon their return to Philadelphia— Cresson thanked me for my verses written in his Album and apologized for not having made his acknowledgment before— Jacob Niles a tax-collector from Randolph called upon me with a tax bill of 33 Cents for the year 1828 for a Swamp in that Town which he said belonged to my father. I paid the tax, and enquired where the Land was, but he could not inform me— He said he would ascertain and let me know—and gave me the names of the Assessors, from whom I propose myself to enquire— I received by express this afternoon a Letter from Mr Nathaniel Curtis enclosing one received from Petty Vaughan, and proposing to call here with Mrs Boylston, Monday Morning, which I answered. Alpheus Spear, my Tenant upon the Mount Wollaston farm was here this Evening, and I promised to call down there again next Wednesday or Thursday. He complains of Trespassers who carry away Seaweed from the beach, and gravel, from the Half-moon, and who are such slim fellows, that nothing can be recovered from them at Law— He put one of them in Jail at Dedham, and after keeping him there a week was obliged to let him out, and pay half the charge and costs of taking and keeping him. I bathed between 5 and 6. and Swam from wharf to wharf and back in 15 minutes. I continued the examination of my fathers early Journals, which are scanty and few— Read some pages in Savage’s Winthrop—wrote a page of Memoranda for my father’s Life— In the afternoon read part of a Chapter of Hutchinson’s 3d. Volume, and in the Evening several Letters of Madame du Deffand— The death-bed repentance of Louis 15. and that of his predecessor, Louis 14. are most instructive moral Lessons— In the agonies of death the remorse of Louis 14. pointed him to his Wars— Speechless in his last Hours, Louis 15. by his Confessor, asks pardon of his people for the scandal of his old age— Oh! may the last moments of my life be free from self-reproach!— There was last Night an occultation of Aldebaran by the Moon— It happened from Midnight till one in the Morning; and having no Telescope here I did not sit up to observe it— But I rose this Morning, before four, and saw with the naked eye, Aldebaran emerged but close upon the borders of the Moon, and Sirius about an hour risen.
23. IV:30— Sunday— Charles returned from New-York.

Mr Brooks of Hingham preached this morning from Acts 15.10. “Now therefore why tempt ye God, to put a yoke upon the neck of the disciples, which neither our fathers, nor we were able to bear?” The Sermon was an ardent appeal in behalf of religious toleration illustrated by a history of the late Act of the British Parliament, for the emancipation of the Catholics of Ireland— The afternoon discourse was upon Justice, from Ezekiel 18.5. [“]But if a man be just, and do that which is lawful and right— 7 and hath not oppressed any
but hath restored to the debtor his pledge, hath spoiled none by violence, hath given his bread to the hungry, and hath covered the naked with a Garment 8. He that hath not given forth upon Usury, neither hath taken any increase, that hath withdrawn his hand from iniquity, hath executed true judgment between Man and Man. 9. Hath walked in my Statutes, and hath kept my judgments, to deal truly: he is just, he shall surely live, saith the Lord God.”— Mr Brooks includes Christian Charity, and benevolence in his idea of Justice— He came and dined with me— Mr Degrand came out from Boston and brought me a Letter from my Son Charles at New-York, written on Thursday the day of his arrival there: his mother and brother with wife and child were there; and expecting to come on, it was uncertain when— My brother, Mr Edward Miller and Mr George W. Beale were here in the Evening. My brothers Son Isaac Hull went into Boston, with Mr Degrand; and shortly after my Son Charles came in from New-York— His mother was taken suddenly and extremely ill, at the City Hotel on Friday Night— John’s Child was also sick, and they had concluded to return to Washington. Charles left New-York in the Steamboat yesterday afternoon; and they were to go this Morning.
24. IV:30. Monday.

I had a nearly sleepless Night, and this has been a distressing day— The fear of what is to come is still more oppressive than the memory of what has past— Let not my trust in God depart from me— I have no other trust— Mr Humphrey is father of Zenas Humphrey, Surveyor of Highways in Braintree, and brought me a tax-bill for land of mine in that Town. I asked what land it was— He did not know. I supposed it to be land rented by Harvey Field, and for which he is to pay the taxes— But of this I am to enquire further. Mr Curtis and Mrs Boylston, came about nine this Morning, and passed great part of the day with me. We read over all the Letters from Petty Vaughan, and I wrote a Letter to him which we all signed, and which Mr Curtis copied into the Letter-Book of the Executors— Mr Curtis is going to-morrow to Princeton, where he is to consult with General Towne, respecting the Sale of part of the Lands there— Around the dwelling house at Princeton, there are near 1600 Acres of land in continuity— The house with 600 acres, are bequeathed after the death of Mrs Boylston, in fee to the Grandson Ward Nicholas. The Executors as Trustees, think it advisable to sell part of the lands, and the 600 Acres adjoining the Mansion, bequeathed eventually to my ward, are to be laid off— I requested particularly the attention of Mr Curtis, that they might be brought in the most compact form, and nearest proximity to the House, possible, with due regard to the quality and kinds of land to give the highest value to the Farm bequeathed; and he promised to give it. Mrs Boylston shewed me the account she had kept of the expenses of education, and maintenance for my two wards— I desired her to continue the same, and to furnish me copies of the Accounts, which I as their guardian must settle at the Probate Office. We had Conversation upon all the other subjects to be acted upon in Execution of the Will— On most of which we cannot definitively proceed, until we ascertain whether we shall receive the funds in the hands of Petty Vaughan— Mr Curtis and Mrs Boylston dined with us, and left us about four in the afternoon— Dr Harris of Dorchester, paid me a morning visit, which he abridged upon finding me engaged in business and promised to call again—
Mrs Boylston and Mr Curtis, were scarcely gone, when two young men came, as visitors of curiosity— Mr Yates of the western part of New-York and Mr Daller, of Pittsburg, Pennsylvania— They were soon succeeded by Mr Jules de Wallenstein a young man, attached to the Russian Legation; the most amiable and intelligent member of the Diplomatic Corps that I have ever known in the United States. He took tea with me and stayed till near nine in the Evening, and we conversed upon European Politicks, and upon Literature, antient and modern— Charles went to Boston this morning and came out in the Evening— Miss Sampson was also here.
25. IV:30. Tuesday.

Charles went to Boston this morning and returned this Evening. Miss Sampson was here— I took a morning bath and swam from wharf to wharf, and back. Met my name-sake there, who went into the water with me— My daily task, with part of a page of Memoranda for the Life of my father, and an unfinished Letter to Dr Waterhouse absorbed the morning— At four in the afternoon, I walked across the hills to the place at the foot of Penn’s Hill; where I found Mr French the Surveyor— Noah Curtis; his Son Samuel, Harvey Field and White French measured off an half Acre of land, eight Rods upon the Plymouth Road, and ten Rods back, which I have agreed to sell to Samuel Curtis, and upon which he proposes to build a house— I measured it also by my pacing, which I found to be three paces to the Rod—that is 5 feet 6 inches to a pace; precisely my own height. My measuring pace is however about 2 inches longer than that of my ordinary gate— I promised to execute the Deed as soon as practicable, but it must now be further delayed to be executed also by Mrs Adams— As I was returning home, I stopp’d for half an hour at Mr John Greenleaf’s— William Greenleaf told me that Mr Thomas Greenleaf had met with an accident this morning in being thrown out of his Chaise, and somewhat bruised. Augustus Whitney came in— He was admitted yesterday as a Freshman at Cambridge. I read this afternoon part of a Chapter of the third Volume of Hutchinson, and this evening some Letters of Madame du Deffand.
26. V. Wednesday.

Commencement day. I had received from President Quincy an invitation to attend at the Exercises of the day and to take Coffee at his house; for which last Sunday I requested his Son to present to him my thanks, and my excuses for declining the invitation; my determination being for the present to avoid going at all into public— I forbore also on this account to give attendance at the installation yesterday of Judge Story as Dane Professor, and of Mr Ashmun as Royall Professor of Law at Cambridge— And shall abstain to-morrow from attendance, at the ΦB.K. Oration and Poem, and at the Boylston-prize Declamations; to which last I have an invitation from Mr F. C. Gray. Charles went into Boston this morning; and returned this Evening. No Letter from John— My tasks— This Diary, the arrears of Index and a page of Memoranda, occupied me to dinner time; so that I had no leisure to read. My brother called this morning, and his Son the Lieutenant passed the day with us.
He began copying the first Diary of my Father— Of November 1755. I have it copied on the blank pages of a Book in which there is already part of his Journal—beginning with his Voyage to France in 1778. After dinner I walked down over Mount Wollaston to the Farm, and had a long interview and ramble with my tenant Alpheus Spear; who pointed out to me all the improvements which he wishes to make, on the place, and which I believe would be judicious— He is anxious about the renewal of his lease, which has only a year from next Spring to run. I authorised him to make some slight repairs upon the barn, and to cut and bring me at his convenience some loads of wood—promising to take the other matters into consideration. I read a few pages of Hutchinson’s third Volume, and looked into the two Volumes of Alden Bradford’s History which Charles brought from Boston—
27. IV:45. Thursday.

Mr Zenas French, a Son of Deacon French deceased, and who now lives at Randolph came and spoke to me of two small lots of cedar swamp in Randolph, which he said had belonged to the Estate of Norton Quincy, which he was inclined to purchase and which he thought worth not more than five dollars an Acre. I enquired where he lived, and proposed to call upon him and ascertain where these grounds be. Charles went into Boston, this morning and did not come out this Evening— He went to Medford— I worked about half an hour with the Spade in my Nursery; but not long enough— I called this Evening at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s and found him well recovered from the accident from which he very narrowly escaped with his life— His daughter Mary Ann was with him, but was not hurt. My tasks absorbed the morning, but I could not write more than one page of Memoirs— I find myself sliding into digressions, which increase my necessary reading, and tend to swell my volume with extrinsic and superfluous matter— This propensity might be checked; but on the other hand the Life must not be a mere extract from Gazettes, or even from my father’s own writings— My plan will take its shape, if it pleases God as I proceed— John Thomas went to Boston this Evening, and brought me out a Letter from my wife, and one from my Son John to Charles, both written from Philadelphia last Monday— My dear wife, and John’s child, are both better— These Letters greatly relieved me from the most intense anxiety.
28. IV:45. Friday.

Mr Humphrey came again with his highway tax-bill for Braintree, but could not inform me where the land for which I was taxed lay; nor what it was. He had seen Harvey Field and my brother; but neither of them could tell; but he referred me to the Assessors Jonathan Wild, Amos Stetson and Elisha Holbrook— After dinner, I rode with John Thomas to Braintree, and found the house of Mr Jonathan Wild— He examined his books but could find no information where or what the land was— There were two Assessments one upon me of one dollar, and one upon the Heirs of Norton Quincy for 25 Cents— He said it was the practice to repeat the Assessments from year to year, without examining
anew the location or value of Lands. That some years since the Assessment upon me had been for 25. Acres valued at 250 dollars, but he knew not where it was, and a dollar was more than three times too much for that, but he promised to make further enquiry, and let me know the result; and if I had been over-taxed to correct the mistake. I then went to Randolph, and found Mr Seth Mann, whom with John Porter, and Henry Alden, Niles the Collector had named to me as the Assessors of that Town— I enquired of him what and where was the land upon which the tax had been assessed upon my fathers heirs— He did not know but referred me to Squire White, a former Assessor to whose house I went, and who did know— He said that my father had paid former assessments to him, and had told him he bought the Land of David Sloane— It was a dead Cedar Swamp, much damaged by fire, about three quarters of a mile from his house, and now bounded by Lands of Obed Jones, Ephraim Jones, Joseph Tower, and the Heirs of Joseph Spear— On my way to Braintree and Randolph, I called at Elisha Turner’s, and his brother Peter called on me this Evening to say that Deacon Spear was Administrator upon the Estate of Boylston Adams, and wished to call on me to-morrow afternoon to confer with me upon the wood-land the title of which is in question between us— I promised to be at home, or to send him word to-morrow Morning. Charles came out to dinner— I worked an hour with the Spade but could not make out to write more than one page of Memoirs—
29. V. Saturday.

Deacon Spear and Peter Turner called upon me this morning, to speak about the lot of Woodland in question, which the Deacon thought it would be as well for me to give to the widow and children of Boylston Adams; but I told him it was not mine to give— We then spoke of having it resurveyed, the time for which will be in October or November— The Deacon advised me also to have the wood cut down, from some of my woodlots, and proposed to do the job for me himself; which I shall take into consideration— Finished bringing up the arrears of my Diary Index, from 2. May 1827. to this day— I went into Boston, and dined at Mr James H. Foster’s— Called at Cary the Stone-cutter’s— His partner was there, and his men were at work upon a moulding of the monument, but they have not yet got the Tablet for the Inscription— I called upon F. C. Gray, with whom I had some conversation respecting the Historical Society and their Transactions. He gave me information respecting their Library, that of the Athenaeum, and the Ebeling Library at Cambridge— Met D. Webster who said he was looking for Mr Vaughan the British Minister, just arrived in the City, and apologized for not having visited me— At Edward Watson’s shop corner of Milk Street I purchased a Cameo-ring with hands joined, for a nuptial present, and two lamps for my morning writing— At Charles’s Office I left an answer to the invitation of Mr and Mrs Brooks for next Thursday Evening. He went this Evening to Medford— I found at Mr Foster’s Elizabeth Norton, daughter of my Cousin that was Elizabeth Cranch— Edward Cranch also came in and was going to Quincy. Miss Norton reminded me much of her mother when young— My afternoon visits were to P. C. Brooks junr, G. Ticknor, Dr Parkman, T. Tarbell, Gardner Green, James Savage,
and judge Davis, none of whom were at home— Mr Samuel W. Cobb I found, very unwell, and in deep despondency; nearly in the last Stage of a Consumption— At Mr B. P. Hall’s Mr Isaac Smith, was confined with a desperate cough taken last week, at the visitation of the Schools. He is eighty years of age, and bent almost double; but cheerful and pleasant in conversation— He shewed me in his bed chamber the Portrait of his Grand-mother and my Great-grandmother Edwards, whose maiden name was Fowle; mother of his father and of my Grandfather Smith— He says she taught him to read, and he takes delight in looking at her Portrait. She died he says in 1761— He was quite concerned that his confinement had prevented him from sharing in the festivities of this Commencement week— At 6 O’Clock I returned to Mr Foster’s, where my Carriage immediately afterwards came; I took Isaac H. Adams out to his fathers and Louisa Foster came to pass a week with her aunt by my invitation— Lieutenant T. B. Adams was here— There was a light sprinkling of rain all the afternoon, and a steady copious rain at Night— I met H. G. Otis this afternoon in the Street and saluted him by name in passing— Met also and spoke to James Savage; and told him I wished to have some historical conversation with him—
30. V. Sunday.

Heard Mr Nicholas Bowes Whitney, of the South Parish of Hingham, in the morning from Psalm 97–1. “The Lord reigneth; let the Earth rejoice;” and in the afternoon from Psalm 4.6. “There be many that say, who will shew us any good.” This Mr Whitney is a man of very good sense, and his Sermons are sensible discourses—but his voice is unmusical, his personal appearance is unpleasing, and his conversation is unpolished and almost rustic— There is however some pleasantry in his temper, and he is fond of relating anecdotes— He came and dined with us, and told me several, about Zabdiel Adams, doubly my father’s first Cousin; and long Minister of Lunenburg— After the afternoon service, I answered a Letter from Mrs Thornton; began one to my Son John, and read the 6th. and 7th. of the Sermons of Dr Freeman’s last Volume; one upon the new Year, and one upon the advantages enjoyed by Christians over the antient Gentiles— I spent the Evening at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s— Mrs Greenleaf, and her niece Mrs Appleton were at Mr John Greenleaf’s, but came home while I was there— Mr Greenleaf gave me three Original Letters from my father, written to my Uncle Cranch; the first dated 2. September 1755— The earliest of my fathers writing that I have yet found—the two others in 1756— Also a Letter from my Mother, without date, but written before my aunt Cranch’s Marriage, and of course when my Mother was under eighteen— Mr Greenleaf gave me two Letters from my father to judge Dawes, dated in 1813. and several Letters between my uncle Cranch, and Robert Treat Paine—and one from Samuel Quincy— Mr Greenleaf came in possession of these Letters, excepting those to judge Dawes, as Administrator upon the Estate of my uncle Cranch. The three early Letters from my father, have to me a deep interest, as they relate to the perplexities of his situation, after he came from College, until he had finally fixed upon his profession. I read them, and most of the other Letters after I returned home. There is so little sympathy with my feelings, relating to all these memorials of my father’s life that I find myself called to distrust them, and to bear in mind the saying of the Grecian sage Cleobulus— ἌριϚον μέτρον
31. IV. Monday.

Mr Whitney paid me a Morning visit, and I spoke to him concerning the obituary inscription, upon the monument to my father and Mother. I thought it proper to consult him as the monument is to be at the side of his pulpit— He will call again to examine the inscription with which I am much dissatisfied, and in which I made this day several alterations and Additions— T. B. Adams made a Copy of it, as it may be ordered on the Tablet— Notwithstanding the Critical Canons of Dr Johnson, I have ventured upon a mixture, both of Latin and English and of Prose and Verse— Dr Johnsons objections to this union appear to me frivolous and pedantic— He might have been told that there is no more impropriety in the introduction of two Languages in an Epitaph, than in his affixing a Latin Motto, to an English Rambler. Nor is the purpose of Epitaphs, as Johnson considers them, solely to give information to the reader concerning the deceased— A higher purpose is to make it instructive to the reader himself— [“]And many a holy text around she strews, That teach the rustic moralist to die[”]— This is on common grave stones; the text is as extraneous to the name and years spelt by the unlettered Muse, as the Latin or the verse upon a Marble Monument— I propose to place over the obituary narrative, the Motto adopted by my father for his arms, from Tacitus—Hist: 1.16. Libertatem, Amicitiam, Fidem Retinebis; and to close the whole with four lines of English verse having reference to the same Motto. Mr Loring and Mrs Whittemore from Hingham were here this afternoon, and in the Evening— I called and spent an hour with G. W. Beale— Charles came out before dinner.

Day. As the Nights lengthen, my rising hour grows later; and I am just now commencing to light my Morning lamp— I am endeavouring also to give myself regularity of occupation by a distribution of my time as uniform as my present circumstances will admit. My task follows in this order— 1. Read 2 or 3. chapters in the Bible— 2. Write the Journal of the preceding day. 3. Write one Letter— 4. Write one page of Memoirs— 5. An hour of exercise. 6. Miscellaneous reading after dinner— This process is almost every day interrupted; by visitors, by visiting, or by small private business of my own. I guard as much as possible against the loss of the first and second points, and therefore take up them before breakfast— All the rest are continually broken in upon, and half the days thenceforth are lost—for every day that passes without the addition of a page of Memoir I account as lost— My reading is slow and unprofitable—my performance immeasurably below my purpose— I have only to implore Peace of mind—health—and perseverance.
